hints_html:
Start with the substitution u = ln x.

Next, do integration by parts twice to solve for the integral you wound up with after the substitution.
hints_latex:
Next, do integration by parts twice to solve for the integral you wound
up with after the substitution.
hints_raw:
Start with the substitution ''u'' = ''ln x''.
Next, do integration by parts twice to solve for the integral you wound up with after the substitution.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
The integral will become less complicated if we make a substitution \(\displaystyle u = \ln(x)\).

First substitution

If \(\displaystyle u = \ln(x)\) then \(du = (1/x)\,dx\). We would like to express \(\displaystyle dx\) in terms of \(\displaystyle u\) and \(\displaystyle du\). Isolating \(\displaystyle dx\) gives \(\displaystyle dx = x\,du\). Solving for \(\displaystyle x\) in \(\displaystyle u = \ln(x)\) gives \(\displaystyle x = e^{u}\) and hence \(\displaystyle dx = e^u\,du\). Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} I = \int \sin(\ln(x))\,dx = \int e^u \sin(u)\,du\end{aligned}\]

First integration by parts

To find this integral, we will need to integrate by parts twice.

Let \(\displaystyle f = e^u\) and \(dg = \sin(u)\,du\). Then \(df = e^u\,du\) and \(\displaystyle g = -\cos(u)\). Thus,

\[\begin{aligned} I &= \int f\,dg \\ &= fg - \int g\,df \\ &= e^u (-\cos(u)) - \int -\cos(u)e^u\,du \\ &= -e^u \cos(u) + \int e^u \cos(u)\,du\end{aligned}\]

Second integration by parts

We repeat the process on the second integral. This time, we let \(\displaystyle v = e^u\) and \(dw = \cos(u)\,du\). Thus, \(\displaystyle dv = e^u du\) and \(\displaystyle w = \sin(u)\). Now we find:

\[\begin{aligned} I &= -e^u \cos(u) + \int v\,dw \\ &= -e^u \cos(u) + vw - \int w\,dv \\ &= -e^u \cos(u) + e^u \sin(u) - \int \sin(u)e^u\,du\end{aligned}\]

Inspect the result

We recognize the integral above as \(\displaystyle I\) and we can now solve for \(\displaystyle I\):

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle I = -e^u \cos(u) + e^u \sin(u) - I\end{aligned}\]

so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2I = -e^u \cos(u) + e^u \sin(u)\end{aligned}\]

Then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle I = \frac{1}{2} e^u (\sin(u) - \cos(u)) + C\end{aligned}\]

We added the arbitrary constant \(\displaystyle C\) because we are computing an indefinite integral.

Bring x back

Finally, the integral we desire can be found by replacing \(\displaystyle u\) by \(\displaystyle \ln(x)\) so that \(\displaystyle e^u = x\) :

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle I = \frac{1}{2} x (\sin (\ln(x)) - \cos (\ln (x))) + C\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The integral will become less complicated if we make a substitution <math>\displaystyle u = \ln(x)</math>.

===== First substitution =====

If <math>\displaystyle u = \ln(x)</math> then <math>du = (1/x)\,dx</math>. We would like to express <math>\displaystyle dx</math> in terms of <math>\displaystyle u</math> and <math>\displaystyle du</math>. Isolating <math>\displaystyle dx</math> gives <math>\displaystyle dx = x\,du</math>. Solving for <math>\displaystyle x</math> in <math>\displaystyle u = \ln(x)</math> gives <math>\displaystyle x = e^{u}</math> and hence <math>\displaystyle dx = e^u\,du</math>. Therefore,

:<math>I = \int \sin(\ln(x))\,dx = \int e^u \sin(u)\,du</math>


===== First integration by parts =====

To find this integral, we will need to integrate by parts twice. 

Let <math>\displaystyle f = e^u</math> and <math>dg = \sin(u)\,du</math>. Then <math>df = e^u\,du</math> and <math>\displaystyle g = -\cos(u)</math>. Thus, 

:<math>\begin{align}
I &= \int f\,dg \\
&= fg - \int g\,df \\
&= e^u (-\cos(u)) - \int  -\cos(u)e^u\,du \\
&= -e^u \cos(u) + \int e^u \cos(u)\,du
\end{align} </math>

===== Second integration by parts =====

We repeat the process on the second integral. This time, we let <math>\displaystyle v = e^u</math> and <math>dw = \cos(u)\,du</math>. Thus, <math>\displaystyle dv = e^u du</math> and <math>\displaystyle w = \sin(u)</math>. Now we find:

:<math>
\begin{align}
I &= -e^u \cos(u) + \int v\,dw \\
&= -e^u \cos(u) + vw - \int w\,dv \\
&= -e^u \cos(u) + e^u \sin(u) - \int \sin(u)e^u\,du
\end{align}
</math>

===== Inspect the result =====

We recognize the integral above as <math>\displaystyle I</math> and we can now solve for <math>\displaystyle I</math>:

:<math> \displaystyle
I = -e^u \cos(u) + e^u \sin(u) - I
</math>
so

:<math> \displaystyle
2I = -e^u \cos(u) + e^u \sin(u)
</math>

Then

:<math> \displaystyle
I = \frac{1}{2} e^u (\sin(u) - \cos(u)) + C
</math>

We added the arbitrary constant <math>\displaystyle C</math> because we are computing an indefinite integral.

===== Bring ''x'' back =====

Finally, the integral we desire can be found by replacing <math>\displaystyle u</math> by <math>\displaystyle\ln(x)</math> so that <math>\displaystyle e^u = x</math> :

:<math>\displaystyle
I = \frac{1}{2} x (\sin (\ln(x)) - \cos (\ln (x))) + C 
</math>
